subject: Home & DIY
title: How Wood Breathes and Moves
description: A 60-second lesson on How Wood Breathes and Moves.

hook.text: A door that sticks in summer but gaps in winter isn't broken. The wood is breathingâ€”absorbing and releasing moisture.

buildup.text: Wood is hygroscopic: it absorbs moisture from humid air and releases it when dry. This causes expansion and shrinkage.

discovery.text: Wood moves mostly across the grain, not along it. A 12-inch board may expand 1/4 inch in width but zero in length.

twist.text: Furniture makers account for this: tabletops attach with slotted screws that let wood slide as it moves.

climax.text: Kiln-dried lumber has 6-8% moisture. Air-dried has 12-15%. Using the wrong one indoors means warping and cracks.

punchline.text: Wood never stops moving. Good builders plan for it.

quiz.question: In which direction does wood primarily expand and contract with moisture changes?
options: Across the grain (width), with virtually no change in length
Along the grain (length) more than in width
Equally in all directions as it absorbs moisture
